ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CAPITATION GRANTS TO AIDED-SCHOOLS


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) what are the current rates of capitation grants given to aided schools; and (b) in view of the contribution to Singapore by aided schools, if he will consider revising the rates to take into account the high cost of running the schools.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the current rates of monthly capitation grants given to Government aided-schools are as follows: 

                            Rate per pupil

Level                          per month



Primary                          $1.10

Secondary                         2.40

Pre-University                    3.50

Junior College                    6.20


    The rates are based on costs incurred on similar items in Government schools.

    My Ministry is aware of the increasing cost in running schools. Hence, the rates of capitation grants are revised periodically. The last revision took effect on 1st January 1982. The next revision is expected to take place at the end of this year.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, in view of the small class size and the additional facilities that are being provided in aided SAP schools, would the hon. Minister of State of Education consider giving them enhanced capitation grants for them to meet the higher recurrent cost?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, the SAP schools are indeed receiving additional capitation grants to make up for shortfalls arising from higher costs and the lower amount of miscellaneous fees collected by them because of the smaller class sizes. The additional grant is based on the difference between the smaller class size of an SAP school and the standard class size of a

Column: 1036

regular secondary school. SAP schools are also given special grants to enable them to run their language laboratories and to provide air-conditioning for their library, music and AVA rooms.

     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, a supplementary question with the intention of seeking clarification. In replying to the questions posed by the Member for Kampong Ubi and also the Member for Punggol yesterday, the Minister of State stated that the request for allocation for funds for ECA and Youth Festival was not approved by the Ministry of Finance but the Ministry of Finance has allowed the Ministry to make use of the Education fund. Can the Minister of State once again confirm that this is so?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, I thought I confirmed it in no uncertain terms yesterday.

SECURITY GUARDS IN SHOPPING CENTRES
(Training)


    2. Dr Ang Kok Peng asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether his Ministry has any plan to require security guards in shopping centres to undergo proper training to make them more effective in dealing with shop-lifters and yet responsible enough not to embarrass or mistreat innocent persons during the performance of their duties.

    The Minister of State for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, security guards are employed by shopping centres to protect their own premises against robbery, theft and mischief. Some shopping centres employ licensed security guards through registered Security Guard Agencies. Others employ security guards or store detectives directly. These guards are not required to be licensed.

    The Police cannot compel shopping centres to send their security personnel for training. However, it is in their interest to ensure that their security guards are trained to perform their duties correctly. Otherwise, they face the risk of civil action for wrongful arrest.

Column: 1037



    Training courses for licensed security guards are available through the Association of Licensed Security and Investigation Agencies. The question whether it should be made a condition of the licence for all licensed security guards to undergo a basic training course in their duties is being considered by the Police. As for those who are not required to be licensed under the Private Investigation and Security Agencies Act, training courses can be arranged for them by the managements. They can approach the Crime Prevention Division of the Singapore Police Force for advice.

PUNGGOL ROAD
(High accident rate)


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether Punggol Road will be widened, in view of the numerous accidents on that road in the last few years because of increasing traffic and, if so, when.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, recent traffic counts conducted by PWD showed that the peak-hour traffic volume along Punggol Road is within the capacity of the road. There is therefore no justification for the widening of this road.

    The high accident rate is due mainly to speeding. Motorists tend to speed along Punggol Road because of the low traffic volume and the absence of intersections. To bring down the speed of vehicles, the PWD has laid speed regulating strips on the road. More safety measures will be carried out by the Department in the next six months. These include the upgrading of the existing mercury vapour lamps to high pressure sodium vapour lamps, marking of lanes with highly visible thermoplastic paint, introduction of more double white lines and reflective button markers to prevent dangerous overtaking, and provision of more footpaths where there are pedestrian movements. The effectiveness of these measures will be

Column: 1038

monitored. Other safety measures will be introduced in future if necessary.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, may I know from the Hon. Minister of State how often are these traffic counts conducted, and when was the most recent traffic count conducted for this stretch of road?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, off-hand, I am not able to tell the hon. Member about the frequency for this particular road or whether there is any fixed frequency in general. I understand this count was done very recently for Punggol, in view of the Question by the hon. Member.

REHOUSING PRIORITY FOR RESETTLEMENT CASES
(Single persons living away from parents)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will give single persons, who are living together as a family but not with parents and who are affected by resettlement, re-housing priority to purchase Housing and Development Board flats and, if not, why not; and (b) whether he will give priority also to grown-up grandchildren who are not living with their parents but with their grandparents and who are affected by resettlement.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, single persons who are living together but away from their parents are not eligible for rehousing priority because they cannot form themselves into a family nucleus. There is a great shortage of flats at the moment and it is necessary for the HDB to apply this rule on family nucleus stringently to curb demand for flats. However, related single persons, such as brothers and sisters, whose parents have both passed away, will be considered as a family nucleus and will qualify for resettlement priority to purchase HDB flats. Single persons affected by resettlement and whose parents are living elsewhere are advised to join their parents. Where this is not possible, they may be allocated 1-room rental flats on a joint allocation basis with at least one other person.

    Grandchildren and their grandparents, if both of whom are alive, will be granted

Column: 1039

resettlement priority to purchase HDB flats. In cases where there is only one grandparent, rehousing priority will be granted if the grandparent forms a family nucleus with one or more of his or her grandchildren, and they can prove that they have been living together on the affected site prior to the resettlement cutoff date.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): May I ask the Minister of State what would be the position of a single resident on a site which is affected by resettlement, if he has not got any family to join and there is nobody else with whom he can "couple", as it were, as suggested by the Minister of State? What does the Ministry expect this man to do? Dig a hole in the ground and live in it?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, in the cases mentioned by the Member for Anson, the HDB will try to arrange for this person to pair up with another single person to live together to rent a flat. In view of our housing shortage, it is necessary for us to insist that there should be at least two persons per household to qualify to rent or purchase flats.

APPLICATION FOR ON E- AND

TWO-ROOM HDB RENTAL FLATS

(Waiting time)


    5. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the estimated average waiting time now for new applicants of one- and two-room Housing and Development Board rental apartments; and (b) whether this waiting time will be shortened over the next two years when more HDB apartments are completed and, if so, by how much.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, on 3rd December last year, in answer to a similar question from the Hon. Member for Kampong Kembangan, I told this House that the waiting period for 1- and 2-room rental flats was estimated to be 1 1/2 - 2 years. Since then, there has been an increase in applications for 1- and 2-room rental flats. This increase was mainly caused by the transfer of a substantial number of 3-room applicants to the 1- and

Column: 1040

2-room registers. The waiting times for rental flats will lengthen to two years for 1-room units and three years for 2-room units.

    The waiting time for rental flats is not expected to be shortened over the next two years. This is because the HDB, in line with the Government's policy to encourage home ownership of flats, has ceased construction of new rental flats.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: The Hon. Minister of State states that, in accordance with Government policy, HDB has ceased constructing 1-room and 2-room flats for rental. What is going to happen to the thousands of people who cannot afford to buy HDB flats at the prices that the HDB is selling as a result of their accounting?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, we can see that the Member is again harping on his old issues. There will be plenty of opportunity for him to raise these issues in the Committee of Supply when we will give him full answers to all the points.

    As far as rental flats are concerned, especially 1-room and 2-room rental flats, he may not be aware that there are about 64,000 1-room rental flats and 44,000 2-room rental flats. This is more than ade- quate to meet the future demand and the policy of the Government is to encourage people to own their homes. We have found that the applicants who register to rent flats have generally income levels not much different from those who apply to buy flats. What they need to do is to perhaps cut down on smoking and drinking and so on. Then they will be able to afford and it will be in their long-term interest to purchase the flats.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I will ask the Hon. Minister of State not to be facetious. It is not a question of these people cutting down on smoking and drinking. They simply cannot afford to buy HDB flats at the prices they are being offered.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, this is a matter of opinion and we do have data to show the actual affordability of the flats.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, is it not true that over the next two years, as the newer flats are available for purchase, there will be substantial numbers

Column: 1041

moving from the 1- and 2-room flats into the purchase flats. These 1- and 2-room flats will be vacant and therefore available for the people that are waiting in the Member for Anson's constituency.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, it is indeed correct. In fact, of the people living in the 1-room and 2-room rental flats, there are about 15,700 applicants who are on the waiting list to purchase flats. These people will be getting their flats probably over the next two to three years, making their flats available to other applicants who need to rent flats.

Column: 1041

NEW APPLICANTS FOR 3-, 4- AND 5-ROOM HDB FLATS
(Waiting time)


    6. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for National Development (a) what is the estimated average waiting time now for new applicants of three-, four- and five-room Housing and Development Board home-ownership apartments; and (b) whether this waiting time will be shortened over the next two years when more HDB apartments are completed and, if so, by how much.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, on 3rd December last year, I told the House that the waiting time for sale flats was 3 1/2 - 4 years in 1981. The situation has improved slightly and new applicants of 3-, 4- and 5-room flats need to wait an average of 3 - 3 1/2 years today.

    Over the next three years, i.e. between now and 1985, the HDB will be completing 120,000 units of public housing. The waiting time for flats will be shortened progressively over this period. After 1985, when the backlog of applicants now on the waiting list is cleared, the waiting time for new applicants will be about two to three years.

Column: 1041

HDB HOUSING ESTATES
(Maintenance services)


    7. Dr Ang Kok Peng asked the Minister for National Development what plan has

Column: 1042

his Ministry for the scheduled, periodic and comprehensive inspection, with appropriate follow-up actions, of Housing and Development Board housing estates to ensure that the problems of low water pressure, frequent lift breakdowns, blocked drainage pipes and systems and water seepage are dealt with systematically and effectively even before individual complaints are received from residents.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, an improvement programme is in progress to tackle the problem of low water pressure at the top two floors of all high-rise HDB blocks. Separate main and down-feed pipes are provided to these floors to increase the flow of water. Of a total of 1,971 blocks involved in the programme, 62% have undergone improvement works, The whole programme is scheduled to be completed by March 1984. Improvements are also being incorporated into all new blocks.

    The HDB regularly maintains its lifts to ensure that they work safely and reliably. Maintenance includes fortnightly servicing, annual tests and regular inspections. Data on defects, breakdowns and repair work are also recorded for computer analysis. Such analysis, in fact, reveals that the average number of breakdowns has decreased over the past five years, from 1.18 breakdowns to 0.83 breakdowns per lift per month, i.e. a 29.6% reduction.

    On the problem of water seepage, the HDB has since 1980 redesigned walls to minimize the problem. Existing flats with water seepage problems undergo remedial work during the repair and redecoration programme that is carried out every four to five years.

    The problem of blocked pipes and systems, however, is difficult to anticipate as it is mainly caused by the indiscriminate disposal of solid wastes that choke the systems. Nevertheless, the HDB has efficient maintenance and repair services to clear blocked systems as and when problems arise.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I must stress that the role of estate maintenance does not belong solely to the HDB. A very important

Column: 1043

part should be played by residents themselves to ensure that the environment they live in is clean, healthy and properly taken care of. Hon. Members will. agree that many of the maintenance problems in our HDB estates are caused by residents themselves. Two ready examples are the misuse of lifts and the blockage of drainage pipes. It is therefore necessary to make residents more conscious of estate maintenance. The HDB, on its part, constantly improves the quality of its maintenance services. In fact, it would not be an exaggeration to say that it has the most comprehensive system of property maintenance in Singapore or perhaps even in the region, a system which operates through a network of 33 Area Offices equipped with many teams of Housing and Maintenance Inspectors.

Column: 1043

HDB FLATS
(Payment of monthly instalments)


    8. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many Housing and Development Board flat owners are currently paying monthly instalment for the purchase of their flat; and (b) how many of them are making their monthly payment through the Central Provident Fund and, of these, how many do not have sufficient money in the Fund to meet their monthly payment in full.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 161,200 flat owners currently paying monthly instalments for the purchase of their flats.

    103,700 pay their monthly instalments through the CPF. Of these, only 19,600 do not have sufficient CPF money to meet their monthly payments in full.

Column: 1043

SHORTAGE OF CAR PARKS
(Solutions)


    9. Mr Goh Chee Wee asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether his Ministry has any short and long term solutions to the shortage of car parks for both private and commercial vehicles; and (b) in view of the scarcity of land and the need to maximise land utilization, whether

Column: 1044

it is feasible to construct multi-storey car parks in Housing and Development Board estates.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the URA has conducted a study of the parking requirements of both light and heavy vehicles. While detailed implementation plans have yet to be worked out, the broad conclusions and recommendations of the study have been accepted by my Ministry. Recommendations incorporating both long term and short term solutions will be implemented. The long term solutions will include the following:-

    (i) Centralized Lorry Parks

    The majority of heavy vehicles will have to be provided with permanent parking areas in centralized parks. Such car parks will be kept out of residential areas because heavy vehicles cause environmental disamenity and may pose a danger to residents, especially children. Subject to availability of land and wherever possible, they will be sited on the fringes of HDB estates for the convenience of most drivers who are HDB dwellers. Overnight lorry parking will also be encouraged in industrial estates where space is available.

    (ii) Car Parks

    More surface car parks will be built in existing HDB estates where demand exceeds supply and if space permits. The HDB has completed surveys in Bedok, Clementi, Ang Mo Kio, Telok Blangah, Toa Payoh and Queenstown. Additional surface car parks will be built in these new towns by early next year. Surveys in other estates are still in progress. Additional car parks will be provided if necessary and possible. Parking provisions for future new towns will take into consideration the results of such surveys.

    (iii) Kerbside Parking

    Orderly kerbside parking for cars and light vehicles will be allowed along selected roads at night in HDB estates. Outside housing estates, overnight kerbside parking will be permitted for heavy vehicles where roads are sufficiently wide. Our roads are built to cope with traffic during peak hours. Overnight kerbside parking would allow us to maximize the use of road surface when the traffic flow is

Column: 1045

much less. The PWD, URA and HDB will ensure that smooth traffic flow will not be compromised by the implementation of kerbside parking.

    (iv) City Parking

    The standards for provision of car parks in private developments will be maintained. The URA will continue to build multi-storey car parks in the city to make up for the shortage of car parks in private developments. By 1985, an additional 2,200 car parking lots in the city will be made available by the URA.

    Pending the implementation of the long-term solutions just described, short-term measures will be taken to alleviate parking problems in HDB estates. These include:-

    (i) temporary kerbside parking in HDB estates along suitable roads for both heavy and light vehicles; and

    (ii) temporary lorry parks outside or at the fringes of HDB estates. These measures will help to stem the pressure for car parking lots in HDB estates while more permanent solutions are implemented.

    Where there is insufficient land for additional surface car parks in HDB estates, the only solution is to build multi-storey car parks. However, I foresee that parking fees will have to increase to cover the higher construction and maintenance costs of the additional parking space.

JUNIOR FLYING CLUB
(Opportunities and facilities)


    10. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health (a) what opportunities and facilities are provided by the Junior Flying Club to meet the enthusiasm and interest of our youth; and (b) what is the total membership of the Club in the years 1980 to 1982 and how many of these members have joined the Republic of Singapore Air Force.

     The Minister of State of Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the Minister of Defence ind Second Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Junior Flying Club (JFC) was formed with the objective of instilling

Column: 1046

interest in flying amongst our students. Members come largely from secondary schools, junior colleges and institutions of higher learning, like the National University of Singapore and the Singapore Polytechnic. The courses on flying are provided free of charge. Students can work towards the Private Pilot's Licence. This particular course is usually over-subscribed. Over the past few years, the Club has increased its intake in order to meet the growing demand among students who are keen to learn how to fly.

    Besides flying, the Junior Flying Club also offers to its members, particularly the younger ones in the age group of 13 - 16 1/2 years, courses in aero-modelling. The Club also encourages visits by students to airbases as well as to other aviation organizations and industries. We also have the Aviation Library made available to all members of the Club.

    The membership of the JFC for the past three years has been about 900, of which 700 are aero-modelling members and 200 are flying members. For the Private Pilot's Licence, the annual intake of students for this particular course has increased by 58% over the last two years. The intake for 1980 was 71 students. This increased to 92 in 1981 and further increased to 112 students for the year 1982.

    To date, of the 205 Junior Flying Club members who had obtained the Private Pilot's Licence, 162 have applied to join the Republic of Singapore Air Force and 108 of them have been enlisted. Of these, 70 of them have already completed their training and obtained their "wings". Another 17 are in the process of pilot training. There are also an additional 15 JFC members who did not take the Private Pilot's Licence but have been recruited into the RSAF and are currently qualified as Air Force pilots.

SINGAPORE BROADCASTING CORPORATION
(Local programmes)


    11. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture whether the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation has any plan to produce more and better local programmes

Column: 1047

that will reflect the lifestyle and aspirations of our people, and if he will outline the plan.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, it has always been SBC's objective to produce programmes that will reflect the lifestyle and aspirations of our people and inculcate those values that will contribute to our progress and stability. There is relatively little problem in the production of information programmes, such as documentaries, current affairs magazines and some children's programmes. But the production of television drama, which is a very effective instrument in conveying values and influencing behaviour, is an entirely different matter. Our,population is too small for us to have a significant number of creative and artistic talent that are needed to produce good dramas. SBC's policy has varied with the language of broadcast. In the case of English, SBC has wisely not tried to produce dramas. In this area, the approach has been to select carefully programmes from the English speaking countries. Malay and Tamil drama requirements are being met with our present resources. The quality of these is being improved with the help of trainers from abroad.

    In terms of the size of viewership for SBC's programmes, Chinese programmes account for the top 10 programmes. SBC, therefore, needs to pay the greatest attention to the content of the Chinese programmes. SBC has depended on dramas produced in Hong Kong and Taiwan. It is unwise to continue to depend entirely on these sources because these foreign productions do not truly reflect our lifestyle, values and aspirations. But the creative talent, that is, scriptwriters, directors and producers, and the artistic talent are found in Hong Kong and Taiwan which have a larger population and an established film industry. We can use the talent in these countries by recruiting and employing them. As long as the themes, treatment and scripts of dramas are guided by Singaporeans with a clear idea of the values and attitudes we want to encourage, such foreign talent can be used effectively. This is what SBC is planning to do.

Column: 1048



    About 20 experienced drama producers, scriptwriters and programme researchers have been engaged from Hong Kong and Taiwan. SBC is engaging full-time local drama performers and giving them intensive training. Past experience has shown that reliance on part-time amateur talent will not improve quality.

    Production facilities are being augmented. Funds have already been pro- vided by the Ministry of Finance for the construction of a large television studio with the full complement of equipment needed for more sophisticated drama productions.

    Within the next few years, SBC will be in a better position to produce local dramas of an acceptable quality and number.

    Similar efforts are also being made to improve other categories of programmes like Musical Variety programmes and Children's programmes.

    Head N -

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead NA-01 of the Main Estimates.*

    Sir, at the present moment a civil servant's pay consists of three components - he basic salary, the NWC allowance and he Annual Wage Supplement, which is in he form of a 13th month payment, and now also a 13 1/2, month payment. When the NWC component and the Annual Wage Supplement component were first introduced, their status was a non-pensionable status. The basic salary has always been pensionable. Recently the Minister for Finance amended the Pensions Act to

Column: 1049

allow the NWC component to be pensionable. In view of that, would he consider amending the Pensions Act to make the Annual Wage Supplement component also pensionable?

     Mr Bernard Chen (Clementi): Sir, in the FY 83 Budget there has been a very substantial increase in manpower expenditure, the average being about 19%, but ranging from a low of 11% to 27%.
